From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Hi Jeff,

On 6 May 2015 at 22:50, Jeff Clune jclune@... [neat]
<neat@=
yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
> We use RMSprop in my lab, but I must admit I ha=
ve not taken the time to figure out what makes it work so well. I=E2=80=99d=
 love to hear your summary!
>

OK I'll give it a shot.

I'm picturing a  2D=
 landscape where x and y are the search variables,
and z is the fitness. We=
 pick a point, calc the gradient w.r.t. x and
y respectively, and move the =
point along x proportionally to x's
gradient, and along y proportionally to=
 y's gradient. So [I think] the
GD path matches that of a hockey puck slidi=
ng down our surface under
gravity (sort of... for one, the puck has no mome=
ntum).

The gradient doesn't tell us how far is a good amount to move at ea=
ch
step, only how far to move in an axis relative to all other axes,
hence =
we introduce a global learning rate (to convert those
proportions to absolu=
te step deltas). The learning rate has to be
found experimentally.

So far =
this is just plain GD.

Question: Does it necessarily follow that we should=
 move faster along
a steep gradient than a shallower one?

Say the x-axis g=
radient is steep, and y describes a long shallow
descent. Plain GD is prett=
y much stationary w.r.t y; it moves along x
to the bottom of a valley. We n=
ow stop moving in x but don't move any
faster in y (assuming there's still =
a y gradient at our new location).

RMSProp follows *all* *steady* gradient=
s at the same speed, regardless
of steepness. Why? because the step size is=
 no longer proportional to
gradient, but instead is proportional to:

(1)  =
   gradient / mean_of_recent_gradients

(actually the recent gradients are =
squared to eliminate the sign,
averaged, and *then* we take the square root=
, hence Root Mean Squared
(RMS-Prop).

So if the gradient is consistent ove=
r recent history then equation (1)
comes to about 1. If however a gradient =
fluctuates a lot then (1) is <
1 (again, the squaring of the historic gradi=
ents is important there).
And if a gradient steadily increases, then it is =
greater than its
recent history and equation (1) is > 1. But I think the tw=
o key cases
are - consistent versus fluctuating.

A gradient that changes a=
 lot probably means we need to slow down
moving along that axis, but a cons=
istent gradient probably means we
should speed up (plain RMSProp doesn't do=
 that really, but you can add
momentum to it).

Here are some nice animatio=
ns I found that might help demonstrate the
difference in pathways of GD ver=
sus RMSProp:

    http://imgur.com/a/Hqolp


There are some other related d=
evelopments I could go into, but I think
that covers the basics for now.

F=
inal point, there's some evidence that saddle points are the dominant
type =
of surface that occur in GD of weights in a neural net, i.e.
points were th=
ere is no strong gradient in any direction - and that's
precisely the scena=
rio where RMSProp moves quickly along a slope and
exits the saddle. If we h=
ad simply tried to speed up the exit by
increasing our global learning rate=
, then the size of the steps would
become far too large once we exited the =
saddle.

That's all far more verbose than I was hoping for. If I'd had more=

time I would have written a shorter email! :)

Anyway hope some of it made=
 sense!

Colin
